item.title: Histograms
item.description: Lets take a look at the second way of visualizing data, we will need to library in the same packages as those in the “Scatter Plot” post. Lets say we would like to make a histogram of all MLB players weights ever recorded, here’s what we would do: library(sqldf) library(Lahman) library(ggplot2) query<-"select weight from Master" result<-sqldf(query) # Visulaizing Data--------- ggplot()+ geom_histogram(data=result,aes(x=weight), color="blue",fill="white",bins=50)+ ggtitle("Body-Weight Distribution for Baseball Players") Color, fill and Bins (Number of Bars) are are editable to your liking.

item.title: Scatter Plots
item.description: Lets learn one way of visualizing data. If we would like to make a scatter plot of data of players careers strike outs versus their career Homeruns, only for those who have hit 400 or more Homeruns this is what we would do. First we need to install and library some packages: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Now we may begin working with our R script: query<-"select playerID,sum(HR) as career_HR,sum(SO) as career_SO from Batting group by playerID having sum(HR)>=400" result<-sqldf(query) ggplot()+ geom_point(data=result,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR),size=3,color="red")+ ggtitle("Career Strikeouts VS Homeruns for Great Hitters")+ xlab("Career Strikeouts")+ ylab("Career Homeruns")
